item.title: wait4 > fork
item.description:

108k forks, 134k waits. That’s odd.

item.title: fd/255
item.description:
Shoot, another attack. Attacker deleted the script after execution. find found nothing. But if bash is running, the script is in memory.

When you open a file in Linux, the kernel creates a file descriptor pointing to an inode. The inode holds the actual data and metadata. rm removes the directory entry - the name - but the inode stays alive as long as something holds a reference.

Bash keeps fd/255 open for the script it’s executing. That’s one reference.
